title: 106_s484
content: The "Bring Them Home Alive Act of 2000" is also known as the American Vietnam War POW/MIA Asylum Program. The "Bring Them Home Alive Act of 2000" grants refugee status in the US to eligible aliens from Vietnam, Cambodia, Laos, China, or former Soviet Union states who deliver a living American Vietnam War POW/MIA. Family members of eligible aliens are also eligible for refugee status. The "Bring Them Home Alive Act of 2000" grants refugee status in the US to eligible aliens from Vietnam, Cambodia, Laos, China, or former Soviet Union states who deliver a living American Vietnam War POW/MIA or are employees in a missing status as a result of the Vietnam War. This term excludes individuals officially determined to be absent without authority. The "Vietnam War" refers to the conflict in Southeast Asia from February 28, 1961, to May 7, 1975. Refugee status is granted to individuals involved in military operations in Vietnam or Southeast Asia in support of the war. The American Korean War POW/MIA Asylum Program is established. The Attorney General grants refugee status in the US to eligible aliens from North Korea, China, or former Soviet Union who deliver a living American Korean War POW/MIA. Family members of these aliens are also eligible. The term "American Korean War POW/MIA" refers to a uniformed service member. The term "Korean War" refers to the conflict on the Korean peninsula from June 27, 1950. It includes individuals in a missing status from the Korean War who are members of a uniformed service or employees. Individuals officially determined to be absent without authority are excluded. During the Korean War from June 27, 1950, to January 31, 1955, individuals in a missing status were those serving in the Korean peninsula or in Asia supporting military operations. The International Broadcasting Bureau is required to promote the "Bring Them Home Alive" refugee program through various media outlets to foreign countries. The International Broadcasting Bureau is mandated to broadcast programming to countries like Vietnam, Cambodia, Laos, China, North Korea, Russia, and other former Soviet Union states. The programming must include at least 20 hours every 30 days and 10 hours per calendar quarter for five years. Additionally, information on the programming should be available on the internet. The International Broadcasting Bureau ensures information on the "Bring Them Home Alive" refugee program is available on its website. Congress suggests that recipients of federal grants broadcasting to specified countries should provide similar information. The term "International Broadcasting Bureau" is defined as the bureau of the United States Information Agency or the Broadcasting Board of Governors. The term "independent states of the former Soviet Union" is defined in this Act as per the FREEDOM Support Act. The curr_chunk is about the roles of the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the Vice President of the United States as President of the Senate.
